title: Hero Spitfire D-Day World War Two pilot dies just 11 days before his 101st birthday
text:
Tony Cooper has died just 11 days before his 101st birthday (Photo: Archant) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A crack Spitfire pilot who helped to support the legendary D-Day attack has died just 11 days before his 101st birthday. 
Hero Tony Cooper cheated death time and time again as he clocked up a staggering 3200 hours on a stunning 160 operational sorties in the Second World War . 
Emotional tributes have poured in for the heroic airman after he flew the Spitfire, the most famous warplane of all time, throughout the last war as he put his life on the line dozens of times. 
Mr Cooper also survived five forced landings, two of them at night, two on fire and one as a result of being hit by enemy ground fire. 
The 64 Squadron flight commander amazingly escaped with just a bump on his head when his Spitfire crashed in Belgium in 1944 after the Allies had turned the tide of war. Read More Tony took part in 160 missions during World War Two (Photo: Archant) Tony Cooper with his beloved Spitfire (Photo: Archant) 
Mr Cooper frequently led his unit on frontline ops as he took the fight to the Nazi enemy straddled across occupied Europe relentlessly. 
Much-loved leader Tony was heavily involved in fighter and ground attack sorties during the build-up to D-Day and during the invasion of Normandy itself. 
He led two missions on June 6, 1944 providing vital fighter cover over Utah and ‘Bloody’ Omaha beaches as Allied troops desperately battled to get a foothold. 
Mr Cooper continued to fly operationally until November 1944. 
He carried out a string of ground attacks, including supporting the iconic if ultimately unsuccessful Airborne assault at Arnhem in Holland. Tony also carried out a string of ground attacks (Photo: Archant) Tony next to the Spitfire that he flew int he war (Photo: Archant) 
Codenamed Operation Market Garden, the heroic attack was immortalised in the Hollywood epic A Bridge Too Far, starring Sean Connery , Robert Redford and Dirk Bogarde. 
Tony returned to his home town of Lowestoft, Suffolk, after the war ended in August 1945. 
He became the fifth generation to work in the family wholesale business, WB Cooper Ltd. 
Tony continued to lead an action-packed life, remaining active into his late 90s. 
The keen swimmer loved to go to the gym to stay fit as well as driving his racy BMW sports car. Tony's adventures in the war were made famous (Photo: Archant) 
Tony was also a devoted family man, having two children, five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. 
A popular member of Lowestoft Rotary Club, he passed away on January 26 at Ritson Lodge Care Home in Hopton-on-Sea. 
Devastated Doris Day, Tony’s partner for nearly 20 years, said: “He was a real gentleman and a true Rotarian. 
“He was very special to a lot of people, as he always cared and looked out for others - he was just amazing.” 
She added: “Tony was unique and one of the wittiest men with such a great sense of humour and was always full of laughter.” Tony next to his Spitfire, which is flew 160 times in World War Two (Photo: Archant) 
Born on February 6, 1916, Mr Cooper was 21 when he was accepted for pilot training in the RAF Volunteer Reserve at Luton. 
Following progression onto a flying instructor’s course, he was posted to Canada in 1940, where he met his beloved wife of 56 years, Pearl Cooper. 
Tony was awarded France’s coveted Legion d’honneur medal in 2015 for helping to liberate the country from Hitler’s forces. 
Barry Scaplehorn, president of Lowestoft Rotary Club, said: “Tony was a gentleman in person and in mind and in every way possible. He treated everyone with such respect. 
“He will be a great loss to the Rotary Club and to the whole of Lowestoft.” He was awarded France's top honour (Photo: Archant) 
Tony’s proud daughter, Alison Bond, 66, said: “He had a zest for life and as a father he was just huge fun. As a child and young girl he was just great fun to be with. 
“When I was at school he would come to pick me up and everybody would want to speak to him as he was so outgoing. 
“He was somebody to look up to and we were very proud of him. We were lucky to have him as he was a fantastic father.” 
Mr Cooper’s funeral will be held on Friday February 24 at 1.30pm in St Marks Church, Oulton Broad, and it’s expected to be packed out with family, friends and admirers. Like us on Facebook
